facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 471 to 476 of 1970 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 471 to 476 of 1970. Appeals by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 29, 1969 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Referred Case No. 34 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: . Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 29, 1969 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Referred Case No. 34 of 1965. C. Chagla, K. Mangachary, A. K. Verma, J. B. DadachanjiO. C. Mathur and Ravinder Narain for the appellant.

facts.text: The assessee firm made applications under S. 26A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 for assessment years 1956-57 to 1961-62.

anchor.surface_text: Application under S. 26A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922  to be hereinafter referred to as the Act  relating to assessment years 1956-57 to 1961-62, relevant accounting years being calendar years 1955, 1956, 1957, 1958, 1959 and 1960 were made by the appellant to the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer accepted the application for assessment year 1956-57 and granted registration by order dated 30-6-1960.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer accepted the application relating to the assessment year 1956-57 and granted the registration asked for, by his order dated 30-6-1960. At the same time he granted renewals of the registration in respect of other assessment years.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax set aside the orders of the Income-tax Officer under S. 33-B after hearing the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: But the Commissioner of Income-tax in exercise of his, powers under S. 33-B of the Act called for and examined the-papers of the case and after hearing the assessee set aside the orders made by the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Assessee appealed to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, which rejected the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee took up the matter in appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal. The Tribunal rejected its appeal. Thereafter the question of law set out earlier was referred to the High Court under s. 66  1  at the instance of the assessee.

facts.text: Question of law referred to High Court under s. 66(1) at instance of assessee; High Court answered in negative in favour of Revenue.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the question of law set out earlier was referred to the High Court under s. 66  1  at the instance of the assessee. The High Court answered that question in the negative, and in favour of the Revenue. Hence these appeals by special leave.

facts.text: Assessee firm constituted under deed of partnership dated 5-2-1955, but deed shows firm came into existence on January 1, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee firm was  companystituted under a deed of partnership dated 5-2-1955 but the deed shows that the firm came into existence on January 1, 1955.

facts.text: Firm consisted of five partners: 1. B. Satyanarayanamurti, 2. B. Bapaiah Pantulu, 3. B. Seetaramaiah, 4. B. Subrahmanyam, 5. B. Rammonanrao (minor represented by father B. Satyanarayanamurty).

anchor.surface_text: The firm  companysisted of five partners namely  1  B. Satyanarayanamurti  2  B. Bapaiah Pantulu  3  B. Seetaramaiah  4  B. Subrahmanyam and  5  B. Rammonanrao. The last one was a minor. The partnership deed shows that he was a party to the same, being represented by his father, B. Satyanarayanamurty.

facts.text: Partnership deed term: profits and losses divided and borne in equal shares.

anchor.surface_text: One of the terms of the partnership deed is that the profit and loss of a business should be divided and borne between the partners in equal shares.

facts.text: Application under s. 26A for AY 1956-57 made on 30-6-1955 with copy of partnership deed.

anchor.surface_text: The application under s. 26A for the assessment year 1956-57 was made on 30-6-1955, the last date for making the application. Along with that application, as required by the rules, a  companyy of the partnership deed was also sent to the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Partners applied to Registrar of Firms on October 18, 1955 to register the firm.

anchor.surface_text: On October 18, 1955, an application was, made by the partners of the firm to the Registrar of Firms to register the firm.

facts.text: Registrar objected by letter dated December 13, 1955 on ground partnership invalid under s. 30 Partnership Act due to minor partner.

anchor.surface_text: The Registrar,. by his letter dated December 13, 1955 objected to the registration of the firm on the ground that the partnership was invalid under s. 30 of the Partnership Act, as one of the partners was a minor.

facts.text: Four adult partners informed Registrar by letter dated December 18, 1955 that minor admitted to benefits only, no share in losses, and agreed to amend application.

anchor.surface_text: After the receipt of that letter, the four adult partners by their letter dated December 18, 1955 informed the Registrar that ,the minor is admitted to the. benefits of the partnership with the  companysent of all the partners. He, has  numberhing to do with the loss of the firm.

facts.text: Registrar registered the assessee firm on January 10, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: After the receipt of that letter, the Registrar of Firms registered the assessee firm, on January 10, 1956.

facts.text: Not known whether copy of letter dated 18-12-1955 was sent to Income-tax Officer and when.

anchor.surface_text: It is  number known whether a  companyy of that letter had been sent to the Income- tax Officer and if so when it was sent.

facts.text: Commissioner concluded partnership void ab initio, letter did not validate deed, terms adversely affected minor.

anchor.surface_text: He came to the  companyclusion that the partnership in question was ab initio void. He rejected the  companytention that the letter sent to the Registrar of Firms validated the partnership deed. He further opined that several of the terms in the partnership deed adversely affected the minor

facts.text: Tribunal upheld Commissioner's conclusions and held applications for registration and renewal invalid.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the Tribunal upheld the  companyclusions reached by the Commissioner. In addition, it held that the applications for registration as well as for renewal did  number  companyform to the requirements of the law and  companysequently they were invalid applications.

facts.text: High Court affirmed Tribunal that partnership not valid in law.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, in an elaborate judgment affirmed the decision of the Tribunal that the partnership was  number valid in law.

facts.text: Supreme Court held applications for registration and renewal did not conform to requirements of law.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the applications for registration and renewal did  number  companyform to the requirements of the law and  companysequently the registration or the renewals as the case may be  companyld  number have been granted.

facts.text: Firm not registered under Indian Partnership Act before s.26A application, nor deed under Registration Act.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee firm was  number registered under the Indian Partnership Act before the application under s. 26A of the Act was made  number was the partnership deed registered under the Indian Registration Act.

facts.text: Partnership deed submitted with application disclosed partnership void under s.30 Partnership Act due to minor.

anchor.surface_text: The Partnership deed submitted along with the application for registration disclosed that the partnership  companystituted under that deed was void in view of s. 30 of the Partnership Act as one of the five partners was a minor.

facts.text: Subsequent alteration of partnership deed term made after time limit for application expired.

anchor.surface_text: Hence the application made for registration was an invalid application. The subsequent alteration of one of the terms of the partition deed, even if validly made, cannot validate the application made because the alteration in question was made, long after the time prescribed

facts.text: No record shows Income-tax Officer condoned delay under proviso to Rule 2.

anchor.surface_text: for making the application had expired and there is  numberhing on record to show that the Income-tax Officer had  companydoned the delay in exercise of his power under the proviso to Rule2.

facts.text: Tribunal found that in applications, letter P not mentioned in column 6; minor's share shown as 1/5th in profits and losses.

anchor.surface_text: It was found by the Tribunal that both in the application made for registration of the firm. as well as in the applications made for renewal of registration in  companyumn 6 of the form letter P was  number mentioned. On the other hand the minors share was shown as 1/5th which means his share both in the profits as well as in the loss.

facts.text: Record does not show if ITO informed of letter to Registrar on 18-12-1955 and when.

anchor.surface_text: As mentioned earlier, the record before us does  number show whether the Income-tax Officer was informed of the letter written to the Registrar of Firms on 18-10-1955, and if so on what date he was informed about it.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals.

anchor.surface_text: In the result these appeals, fail and they are dismissed.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the assessee firm is entitled to registration under s. 26A of the Act

anchor.surface_text: That question is Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the assessee firm is entitled to registration under s. 26A of the Act. Application under S. 26A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922  to be hereinafter referred to as the Act  relating to assessment years 1956-57 to 1961-62, relevant accounting years being calendar years 1955, 1956, 1957, 1958, 1959 and 1960 were made by the appellant to the Income-tax Officer.

issues.text: Whether the partnership was ab initio void under s. 30 of the Partnership Act as one of the partners was a minor

anchor.surface_text: The Registrar,. by his letter dated December 13, 1955 objected to the registration of the firm on the ground that the partnership was invalid under s. 30 of the Partnership Act, as one of the partners was a minor.

issues.text: Whether the applications for registration and renewal conformed to the requirements of the law including Rules 2, 3, 4 and 6

anchor.surface_text: The Partnership deed submitted along with the application for registration disclosed that the partnership constituted under that deed was void in view of s. 30 of the Partnership Act as one of the five partners was a minor. Hence the application made for registration was an invalid application. The subsequent alteration of one of the terms of the partition deed, even if validly made, cannot validate the application made because the alteration in question was made, long after the time prescribed for making the application had expired and there is nothing on record to show that the Income-tax Officer had condoned the delay in exercise of his power under the proviso to Rule2.

issues.text: Whether the letter written by the adult partners to the Registrar of Firms on 18-12-1955 validated the partnership

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the applications for registration and renewal did not conform to the requirements of the law and consequently the registration or the renewals as the case may be could not have been granted. In that view we have not thought it necessary to go into the question whether the partnership was validated as a result of the letter written by he adult partners to the Registrar of Finns on 18-12-1955.

issues.text: Whether in column 6 of the forms under Rules 3 and 6, failure to indicate with letter 'P' that the minor was not liable for losses invalidated the applications

anchor.surface_text: It was found by the Tribunal that both in the application made for registration of the firm. as well as in the applications made for renewal of registration in column 6 of the form letter P was not mentioned. On the other hand the minors share was shown as 1/5th which means his share both in the profits as well as in the loss.

issues.text: Whether substantial compliance with the requirements of s. 26A and rules is sufficient or strict compliance is required

anchor.surface_text: for making the application had expired and there is nothing on record to show that the Income-tax Officer had condoned the delay in exercise of his power under the proviso to Rule2. holdings.text: From the facts set out above, it is clear that the applications made by the partners of the firm did not comply with the requirements of the rules. Hence those applications cannot be considered as valid applications

anchor.surface_text: As mentioned earlier, the record before us does not show whether the Income-tax Officer was informed of the letter written to the Registrar of Firms on 18-10-1955, and if so on what date he was informed about it. From the facts set out above, it is clear that the applications made by the partners of the firm did not comply with the requirements of the rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative facts show non-compliance with rules

holdings.text: before a person can claim the benefit of s. 26A, he must strictly comply with the requirements of that section. In view of sub-s. (2) of that section, he is also required to comply with the requirements of the relevant rules. Failure to comply either with the requirements of sub-s. (1) or sub-s. (2) of s. 26A, disentitles the applicant to the benefit of that section

anchor.surface_text: In Rao Bahadur Ravulu Subba Rao and ors. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 1 , Venkatarama Ayyar J. speaking for the Court observed Thus, if a firm is registered, it ceases to be a unit for purposes of taxation and the profits earned by it are taken, in accordance with the general law of partnership to have been earned by the individual partners accord- ing.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following precedents like Ravulu Subba Rao, N.T. Patel, Khanjan Lal; registration benefit is statutory creature requiring strict compliance

holdings.text: Section 185 (2) of the 1961 Act is not retrospective in operation nor were the requirements of that provision complied with

anchor.surface_text: In support of his plea he placed reliance on s. 185 (2) of the Income-tax Act, 1961. We are unable to accede to that contention ? Section 185 (2) of the 1961 Act is not retrospective in operation nor were the requirements of that provision complied with.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application; no retrospectivity and factual non-compliance

holdings.text: we have not thought it necessary to go into the question whether the partnership was validated as a result of the letter written by the adult partners to the Registrar of Firms on 18-12-1955

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the applications for registration and renewal did not conform to the requirements of the law and consequently the registration or the renewals as the case may be could not have been granted. In that view we have not thought it necessary to go into the question whether the partnership was validated as a result of the letter written by he adult partners to the Registrar of Finns on 18-12-1955.
